awd_titl_txt: Parenting, Preschool, and the Production of School Readiness and Later Academic Outcomes
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will combine large data sets from Head Start and other publicly provided pre-kindergarten programs, parental involvement and experiments to test the effects of parenting education and length of day care on long-term child educational outcomes.  The project will study how extra time in summer school just before kindergarten affect student outcome; the effects of parenting education using video interactions on parenting skills and subsequent effects on child educational outcomes; whether extending Head-Start classes from half day to full day improves child academic outcome, and the use of a different methodology to study the effects of extending the Head-Start program to a full day rather than to a half day.  This research project is one of the first to study Head Start in a very comprehensive way.  Given the resources spent on Head Start and other pre-school programs as well as the effects these programs could have on human capital development, this research deals with a very important subject.  The results of the research project will provide important inputs into the formulation of education and human capital policies in the US.  This will help establish the US as the global leader in early childhood education.


This research project will combine large administrative data sets on Head Start, parental involvement, and rigorous methodologies, including field experiments and regression discontinuity (RD) to investigate the effects of parenting education on parental skills and subsequent long-term educational outcomes of young children. The research is made up of four projects that includes the study of the effects of extra pre-K summer school on children?s readiness for kindergarten, the effects of parenting education using video interaction with children on parental skills and the last two projects will use multi-site experimental methods and RD to study the effects of expanding Head Start to full day programming using variation in the timing of the roll out of the program across counties as an instrument.  This project leverages rigorous methods and innovative programmatic approaches to add additional insights into the literature on early childhood education as well as provide important inputs into policy making.  Understanding whether and how early childhood educational interventions work is important for economic science as well as educational and human capital policy.  The results of this research project will help to establish the U.S. as the global leader in early childhood education research and policy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
This project supported multiple studies investigating the interaction between parental and public investments in young children’s early care and education. The overarching aim was to illuminate central questions in early childhood care and education (ECE) policy, providing evidence on (1) the role of parents and preschool programs in facilitating children’s human capital development and (2) the impact of public programs on children and families with a particular focus on the importance of structural features including the length of the program day. Throughout the associated projects, the research teams leveraged rigorous methods, including field experiments and newly assembled and cleaned archival and administrative data, along with innovative programmatic approaches and policy changes to fill important gaps in the literature on early childhood education and answer relevant questions for policymakers and researchers. These projects relied on various policy and programmatic efforts in which public resources are directed to the early childhood years, including public preschool, Head Start, kindergarten in public schools, child care subsidies, and housing assistance. Central findings include: (1) investments in early childhood can have important short- and long-term effects on children’s outcomes, particularly when they result in changes to parental behavior and the early environment; (2) program features matter in realizing outcomes for both children and families, with longer-duration programming in early childhood influencing families’ time use and increasing mothers' labor force participation; and (3) ECE policies that seek to both facilitate children’s development and support parental education, training, and employment should build on this literature to better incorporate in design when such policies are effective and when they fail to produce benefits in excess of costs. In particular, filling gaps in the current ECE programming landscape may provide opportunities to maximize both aims, relative to the inputs in human capital development that children would otherwise experience in their early years.

 


Last Modified: 01/21/2025
Modified by: Chloe Gibbs
